name: The Lions of Al Rassan
description: A turn-based civilization game set in a fantasy analog of medieval Iberia. Three faiths and five kingdoms circle one another as a golden age ends — and something dark gathers across the sea.
source: Inspired by 'The Lions of Al Rassan' by Guy Gavriel Kay

civilizations.name: Kingdom of Ragosa
civilizations.description: The most cultured of the Asharite kingdoms, Ragosa is a city of scholars, poets, and merchants. Rich in dinars and faith, it has long maintained a precarious peace through diplomacy and patronage.
specialAbilities: Cultural Patronage: Gain +10% faith when constructing cultural buildings
City of Scholars: Libraries cost 10 dinars less to build
civilizations.flavor: The city of Ragosa shines gold in the afternoon light, its minarets and counting-houses rising above the river. Here the poets compose, the physicians study, and the Kindath trade in peace. It cannot last.

civilizations.name: Emirate of Cartada
civilizations.description: The most aggressive of the Asharite kingdoms, Cartada's armies are feared from the northern passes to the southern straits. It hungers for the ruins of the old Caliphate.
specialAbilities: Aggressive Expansion: Units gain +5 combat strength when attacking
City of Swords: Barracks cost 10 dinars less to build
civilizations.flavor: Cartada's banner is the red sword on black. Its Emir has unified the western Asharite cities through conquest and fear. His ambitions do not stop at the borders of Al Rassan.

civilizations.name: Kingdom of Valledo
civilizations.description: The strongest of the Jaddite kingdoms, Valledo's knights and cavalry press south in the name of Jad. Its faith is burning and its armies are disciplined.
specialAbilities: Reconquista Drive: Gain +10 faith when capturing Asharite settlements
Mountain Fortress: Units defending in mountains gain +10 combat strength
civilizations.flavor: The kings of Valledo kneel before the disk of Jad and rise with fire in their eyes. They speak of reclaiming the peninsula. They are no longer speaking only in prayers.

civilizations.name: Kingdom of Ruenda
civilizations.description: The Jaddite kingdom of the eastern coast, Ruenda is a kingdom of merchants and cavalry. It trades as readily as it fights, and its horses are the finest in the peninsula.
specialAbilities: Merchant Cavalry: Trade route income is boosted when horses are plentiful
Sea Traders: Ports generate +2 extra trade_goods per turn
civilizations.flavor: Ruenda sits astride the coastal road and grows rich from it. Its king is practical: alliances are tools, wars are expenses, and the sea is an opportunity.

civilizations.name: The Kindath
civilizations.description: The silver-robed wanderers, the Kindath are physicians, merchants, and astronomers. They have no kingdom, only a quarter in every city. Rich in trade goods and dinars, they have no army — only their wits.
specialAbilities: Diaspora Network: Generate +1 dinars from every friendly settlement on the map
Silver Road: May offer trade deals with any civ regardless of diplomatic state
civilizations.flavor: The Kindath follow the two moons that are their holy symbol. They are welcome everywhere and safe nowhere. They have survived three hundred years of al-Rassan by being indispensable.

resources.name: Dinars
resources.description: Currency and trade wealth. Dinars flow through the great markets of Al Rassan, funding armies, bribing enemies, and building wonders.

resources.name: Grain
resources.description: Food and population support. Without grain, cities starve, armies dissolve, and kingdoms fall.

resources.name: Soldiers
resources.description: Military manpower. Every levy raised, every fort garrisoned, every wall defended costs soldiers.

resources.name: Faith
resources.description: Religious and cultural influence. Faith inspires sacrifice, justifies conquest, and binds a people together — or tears them apart.

resources.name: Trade Goods
resources.description: Luxury goods from ports and cities. Silk, spice, silver, and dye — the wealth that cannot be made by sword.

resources.name: Horses
resources.description: Cavalry production. The great horse herds of Al Rassan are the foundation of its armies. A kingdom without horses is a kingdom on foot.

techTree.name: Crop Rotation
techTree.description: Systematic alternation of crops to restore soil fertility and increase yields.

techTree.name: Trade Networks
techTree.description: Organized routes linking cities, enabling efficient movement of goods and currency.

techTree.name: City Walls
techTree.description: Permanent stone fortifications encircling settlements to resist siege and assault.

techTree.name: Levy Infantry
techTree.description: Organization and training of citizen levies into effective infantry formations.

techTree.name: Horsemanship
techTree.description: Advanced techniques of horse breeding and cavalry training.

techTree.name: Siege Craft
techTree.description: The art of taking fortified positions — ladders, rams, and the first crude siege engines.

techTree.name: Patronage of the Arts
techTree.description: Royal support for poets, scholars, and architects, raising cultural prestige.

techTree.name: Irrigation
techTree.description: Canal systems and water wheels that bring river water to arid fields.

techTree.name: Shipbuilding
techTree.description: The construction of seaworthy vessels for trade and war on the Inner Sea.

techTree.name: Border Scouts
techTree.description: Light skirmishers trained to range ahead of armies and report on enemy movements.

techTree.name: Professional Army
techTree.description: Standing armies of paid soldiers replacing the seasonal levies of the old order.

techTree.name: Religious Zeal
techTree.description: The hardening of faith into ideology — soldiers who fight for their god, not their king.

techTree.name: Diplomatic Court
techTree.description: Formal institutions for receiving ambassadors and conducting statecraft.

techTree.name: Heavy Artillery
techTree.description: The trebuchet and its kin — city-smashing engines that redefine what walls mean.

techTree.name: Spice Trade Routes
techTree.description: Secured routes for the lucrative eastern spice trade, enriching coastal kingdoms.

techTree.name: Fortified Cities
techTree.description: The full transformation of a city into a fortress, with towers, moats, and killing grounds.

techTree.name: Astronomy
techTree.description: The study of the heavens — navigation, calendar, and a deeper understanding of the divine order.

techTree.name: Military Orders
techTree.description: Holy knights and warrior-monks who combine religious devotion with martial excellence.

techTree.name: Tax Reform
techTree.description: Restructured tax collection that raises revenue but breeds resentment among the taxed.

techTree.name: Cavalry Tactics
techTree.description: Refined doctrines of cavalry use — flanking, pursuit, and the coordinated charge.

techTree.name: Grain Reserve
techTree.description: Strategic stores of grain that protect against famine and winter starvation.

techTree.name: Mercenary Contracts
techTree.description: Legal and financial frameworks for hiring and retaining professional mercenary companies.

techTree.name: Holy War
techTree.description: The religious sanction of total war against the unbeliever — every soldier a martyr.

techTree.name: Resistance to the Muwardis
techTree.description: Hardened tactics and fortifications developed specifically to counter the Muwardi invasion style.

techTree.name: The Golden Age
techTree.description: A flowering of art, science, and culture that will be remembered long after the kingdoms are dust.

techTree.name: Grand Coalition
techTree.description: A desperate alliance of former enemies who set aside blood feuds before a greater threat.

techTree.name: The Last Stand
techTree.description: When your back is against the wall, the city itself becomes a weapon.

techTree.name: The Poet-Kings
techTree.description: The final flowering of the Asharite golden age — rulers who are also artists, whose courts outshine any in the world. But something dark gathers across the sea.

techTree.name: Alliance with the Kindath
techTree.description: A formal compact with the Kindath diaspora, granting access to their vast trade networks.

techTree.name: The Reconquista
techTree.description: The holy campaign to reclaim every inch of the peninsula for Jad — a generational crusade.

buildings.name: Granary
buildings.description: A fortified storehouse for grain, protecting against famine and enabling larger populations.

buildings.name: Market
buildings.description: A permanent trading space that attracts merchants and increases commercial activity.

buildings.name: Barracks
buildings.description: Permanent training grounds that maintain a ready supply of levied soldiers.

buildings.name: Stables
buildings.description: Well-managed stables for horse breeding and cavalry training.

buildings.name: Port
buildings.description: A fortified harbor enabling ocean-going trade and naval operations.

buildings.name: Stone Walls
buildings.description: Permanent stone fortifications that make assault costly and siege necessary.

buildings.name: Mosque / Cathedral
buildings.description: A house of worship that raises faith and brings spiritual stability to a settlement.

buildings.name: Library
buildings.description: A repository of knowledge that draws scholars and raises the cultural prestige of a city.

buildings.name: Observatory
buildings.description: A tower for studying the stars — navigation, astrology, and the sacred mathematics of the heavens.

buildings.name: Embassy
buildings.description: Permanent quarters for foreign representatives, enabling sophisticated statecraft.

buildings.name: Citadel
buildings.description: A fortress within the city — a last redoubt when the walls are breached.

buildings.name: Kindath Counting House
buildings.description: A Kindath merchant house with connections to every port and market in the known world.

buildings.name: Water Wheel
buildings.description: A mechanical wheel driven by a river current, powering mills and irrigation channels.

buildings.name: Siege Workshop
buildings.description: A specialized facility for building and maintaining siege engines.

units.name: Levy Spearman
units.description: Citizen soldiers armed with spears — the backbone of every army in Al Rassan.
units.flavor: They carry the spears their fathers carried. Most will return to the fields when the fighting is done. Most.

units.name: Light Cavalry
units.description: Mounted skirmishers and raiders who strike fast and retreat faster.
units.flavor: They ride like wind across the plains of Al Rassan, appearing where no army expects them.

units.name: Scout
units.description: Light irregular troops trained to range ahead of armies and map terrain.
units.flavor: What you do not know can kill you. Scouts are the answer to that axiom.

units.name: Siege Crew
units.description: Specialists in assault — carrying ladders, building rams, and creeping forward under fire.
units.flavor: Slow work. Bloody work. The only work that takes a fortified city.

units.name: War Galley
units.description: An oared fighting ship capable of ramming, boarding, and protecting trade lanes.
units.flavor: On the Inner Sea, the galley is king. He who controls the sea-lanes controls the trade.

units.name: Heavy Cavalry
units.description: Armored horsemen capable of shattering infantry formations and overrunning artillery.
units.flavor: Nothing on the battlefield sounds like a charge of heavy horse. Nothing produces the same answer in the gut.

units.name: Knight-Commander / Ghazi
units.description: An elite warrior-leader whose faith and skill inspire nearby troops to extraordinary feats.
units.flavor: Whether he rides under the star of Jad or the crescent of the Ashar, he fights as if god is watching.

units.name: Trebuchet
units.description: A massive counterweight siege engine capable of demolishing city walls from a safe distance.
units.flavor: The city wall that took a hundred years to build falls in a morning when the arm swings.

units.name: Mercenary Company
units.description: A professional fighting force loyal to whoever pays — skilled, expensive, and reliable while the coin holds.
units.flavor: They fight for pay, not faith. In Al Rassan, that sometimes makes them the most trustworthy soldiers in a city.

units.name: Court Guard
units.description: Trained bodyguards and city defenders, skilled at protecting people rather than taking ground.
units.flavor: The Kindath have always needed protection. They learned, long ago, to provide it for themselves.

events.name: Drought
events.description: A season of no rain. The crops wither in the field and the granaries empty faster than they fill.
events.flavourText: The sky has not broken in forty days. The farmers watch the horizon and pray to whatever god they follow.

choices.label: Tax the merchants to buy grain
Release soldiers to work the fields

events.name: Plague in the City
events.description: A pestilence moves through the crowded streets. The physicians are overwhelmed. The dead are not yet counted.
events.flavourText: They are burning the houses where the sick have died. The smoke is visible from the palace.

effects.text: The gates are sealed. Trade stops. The plague is contained, at cost.

choices.label: Open the temples and pray for deliverance

effects.text: The priests burn incense day and night. Some say it helps.

events.name: Revolt in the South
events.description: When stability collapses, the governed remember that they outnumber the governors.
events.flavourText: The garrison commander sends a single message: the south is burning.

choices.label: Send the army to suppress the revolt

effects.text: The revolt is put down with considerable violence.
The rebels accept terms. The kingdom is weaker but still whole.

events.name: Assassination
events.description: A diplomat, a general, or a beloved advisor is found dead. The timing is, of course, suspicious.
events.flavourText: A knife in the dark is cheaper than an army, and more reliable.

effects.text: The investigation yields nothing certain. Suspicion poisons the court.
Retaliation comes swift and not always accurate.

events.name: Deserters
events.description: When armies are not paid or fed, soldiers find better uses for their legs.
events.flavourText: Half the garrison was gone by morning. They left their spears in the armory, as if they expected to come back for them.

choices.label: Let them go — they cannot be trusted now
Force men into service by any means

events.name: Famine
events.description: Not drought, not war — just the slow arithmetic of too many mouths and too little grain.
events.flavourText: The bread riots began in the market quarter. By evening they had reached the palace gates.

choices.label: Purchase emergency grain from foreign traders

effects.text: They did not understand.

events.name: The Treasury Is Empty
events.description: The accountants deliver their news in the smallest possible voice. There is no coin left.
events.flavourText: You cannot pay the garrison. You cannot pay the merchants. You can barely pay the accountants.

choices.label: Debase the coinage — mix in copper

effects.text: The merchants notice immediately. Everyone notices immediately.

events.name: Border Raid
events.description: With war declared, the frontier becomes a slaughterhouse of small actions and burning villages.
events.flavourText: The border villages are sending refugees. Behind them, smoke.

effects.text: The raids slow but do not stop.

events.name: A Poet Arrives at Court
events.description: A wandering poet of great skill appears at your court, seeking patronage — and offering genius in return.
events.flavourText: He arrived at evening, riding a borrowed mule, and by morning had composed three odes that will outlast any king.

choices.label: Offer a modest gift and let them travel on

events.name: Trade Fleet from the East
events.description: A fleet of eastern merchants has arrived in your harbors, laden with goods the like of which the peninsula has not seen.
events.flavourText: The harbor smells of spice and the merchants speak in six languages. It is, for a moment, like the world is not ending.

choices.label: Welcome the fleet with generous terms
Tax the fleet heavily at the harbor

events.name: A Star Falls
events.description: A brilliant light crosses the night sky and falls into the sea. The astronomers argue about what it means.
events.flavourText: The scholars say it is only rock and fire. The priests say it is a message. Both are probably right.

choices.label: Interpret it as a divine omen
Study it as a natural phenomenon

effects.text: The astronomers record the trajectory, the brightness, the silence after. Knowledge is its own kind of faith.

events.name: A Mercenary Captain Offers Service
events.description: A hardened mercenary captain, his company battle-tested and looking for work, has come to your court.
events.flavourText: He is polite. His men are not. His price is fair. His loyalty will last exactly as long as his contract.

effects.text: The captain bows politely and rides to your nearest rival.

events.name: Harvest Festival
events.description: The harvest has come in and the people are celebrating. This is what a kingdom is for.
events.flavourText: For one night, the wars are somewhere else. The fires are for dancing, not burning.

events.name: A Caravan Arrives
events.description: A trading caravan, laden with goods from distant lands, has arrived at your gates.
events.flavourText: The camel drivers will not say where they came from. The goods speak for themselves.

choices.label: Trade fairly and send them on with contacts

events.name: Skilled Craftsmen Seek Work
events.description: A guild of master craftsmen — stonemasons, carpenters, ironworkers — is looking for a patron.
events.flavourText: They build things that last. In Al Rassan, this is either a blessing or a taunt.

choices.label: Employ them and set them to work

effects.text: The new buildings rise quickly. The city feels, briefly, like a city with a future.

choices.label: Send them to a neighboring kingdom

effects.text: The craftsmen move on to more welcoming lands. You see their work in an enemy's city a season later.

events.name: The Great Horse Fair
events.description: Breeders from across the peninsula have gathered to trade the finest horses in Al Rassan.
events.flavourText: A good horse is worth three soldiers, or so the cavalry commanders say. The cavalry commanders are not wrong.

choices.label: Sell from your own herd at the fair

events.name: Persecution of the Kindath
events.description: Rising religious tensions have turned into violence against the Kindath quarter. The silver-robed are not safe.
events.flavourText: They have survived worse than this. They have always survived. So far.

effects.text: The Kindath quarter empties. The counting-houses are shuttered. The city is less wealthy for it.
The court guard holds the streets. The Kindath survive. The city does not forget.

events.name: The Call to Holy War
events.description: The clerics are preaching in every cathedral: the time has come to reclaim the peninsula for Jad.
events.flavourText: The sun disk blazes on every banner. The priests have not spoken like this in a generation.

choices.label: Stay out of other kingdoms' holy wars

effects.text: The clerics preach of cowardice. The people begin to wonder if they are right.

events.name: Muwardi Preachers Arrive
events.description: Preachers from across the sea have come, calling the Asharite kingdoms to a purer, harder faith.
events.flavourText: They wear plain wool and eat nothing but dates. They look at the libraries and mosques of Al Rassan with undisguised contempt.

choices.label: Welcome them — their zeal may be useful
Expel them — their faith is not our faith

events.name: A Holy Relic Is Discovered
events.description: Workmen digging foundations have unearthed something ancient — a relic the priests insist is sacred.
events.flavourText: Whether it is truly what they say it is, no one can prove. Whether people believe it — that is already decided.

choices.label: Display the relic in the great temple
Give it to the scholars to study

events.name: An Interfaith Marriage Is Proposed
events.description: A noble family proposes a marriage that would cross the boundaries of faith. In Al Rassan, this has happened before.
events.flavourText: In the old days of the Caliphate, such marriages were unremarkable. These are not the old days.

choices.label: Allow the marriage — family above faith

events.name: The Inquisition Begins
events.description: The church hierarchy has begun investigating heresy and apostasy with new vigor.
events.flavourText: The inquisitors are very polite. They write down everything you say.

effects.text: The fires burn bright. The streets are quieter after.

events.name: The Muwardis Cross the Straits
events.description: Ships have been seen crossing the southern straits. The watching parties say they fly Muwardi banners.
events.flavourText: It was always going to happen. The question was only when.

effects.text: The Muwardis have been seen on the straits. What was rumor is now fact.

events.name: The Muwardi Vanguard
events.description: Advance units of the Muwardi army have been reported in the south. The invasion is no longer a rumor.
events.flavourText: The scouts describe an army that marches in silence and prays five times a day. They do not trade. They do not negotiate.

choices.label: Ignore it — it is not yet your problem

events.name: The Muwardi Army Lands
events.description: The Muwardi host has crossed the sea in force. They are on the peninsula. The golden age is over.
events.flavourText: From the towers of Silvenes you can see the campfires. There are many campfires.

choices.label: Prepare every defense — this is the war

effects.text: The Muwardis have landed in force. The peninsula will never be the same.

choices.label: Send an envoy to seek terms

effects.text: The Muwardi commander returns the envoy's head. There are no terms.

events.name: The Last Battle of Al Rassan
events.description: The Muwardi host closes on the last free cities. There will be no more retreats.
events.flavourText: Every army that Al Rassan has ever fielded stands in one plain. Every banner. Every god. Everyone who is left.

choices.label: Stand together — all faiths, all swords

effects.text: The last armies of Al Rassan gather. Whatever comes next, they face it together.

events.name: The Half-Blood
events.description: A figure appears in the story of Al Rassan: someone born between two faiths, belonging to neither, claiming both.
events.flavourText: He was Asharite and Jaddite by blood. He was physician and soldier. He was the kind of person that Al Rassan produces, and that Al Rassan will not be able to produce for much longer.

effects.text: In Al Rassan, the children of three faiths have always walked the same streets. But something is ending.

events.name: The Three Children of Jad
events.description: The Jaddite priests gather to remind their congregations of their sacred purpose.
events.flavourText: Jad made the sun and set it in the sky to give light to his children. His children have been in the dark too long.

effects.text: Jad made the sun and set it in the sky. The kingdom answers with drawn swords.

events.name: The Night of the Two Moons
events.description: The Kindath holy night, when both moons are full. A time of prayer, remembrance, and longing.
events.flavourText: They gather quietly, without announcement. They light their candles and speak the old words. They have been doing this for a thousand years.

events.name: A Golden Age Ends
events.description: The poet-kings have reached their height. The golden age of Al Rassan is complete. And something in the south is stirring.
events.flavourText: The poems will be read for a thousand years. The poets will be dead in twenty.

choices.label: Accept that the age is ending

effects.text: The age of the poet-kings has reached its height. The Muwardis are coming. Al Rassan will not survive unchanged.

events.name: The New Moon Feast
events.description: The Asharite new moon celebration brings the city together in a brief moment of peace.
events.flavourText: The lanterns are lit in every window. For one night, the fighting is somewhere else.

choices.label: Keep the feast simple this year

effects.text: The feast passes without grand celebration. The people notice.

events.name: The Last Caliph Is Dead
events.description: The last Caliph of the old order has died in Qurtaba, unmourned by some and sincerely mourned by others.
events.flavourText: He was not a great man. But he was the last of a kind of man. With him dies the idea that Al Rassan was one thing.

choices.label: Note the passing of an age

effects.text: The last Caliph has died in Qurtaba. Al Rassan is now a land of fragments, and everyone knows it.

events.name: Whispers of War
events.description: The souks are full of rumors. The ambassadors are sending coded messages. War is being discussed.
events.flavourText: Whispers travel faster than armies. By the time the armies move, everyone already knows what they will do.

effects.text: Whispers of war spread through the souks and cathedrals alike. No one is surprised.
You dismiss the rumors. Some people believe you.

events.name: The Silver Road
events.description: The ancient Kindath trade network activates, bringing unusual wealth to those connected to it.
events.flavourText: Silver moves where armies cannot follow. This has always been the Kindath gift.

events.name: Siege and Counter-Siege
events.description: Cities are invested and relieved, walls are manned and breached. War has its own terrible logic.
events.flavourText: The besiegers dig their trenches. The besieged count their grain. Both sides pray for relief.

effects.text: The walls are manned. The siege settles into its grim arithmetic.

events.name: Scorched Earth
events.description: As armies cross the border, the fields burn. It is not clear which side is burning them.
events.flavourText: The granaries are torched before the army retreats. Hungry soldiers are bad soldiers. Hungry civilians are worse.

effects.text: The fields are burned. The enemy advances through ash.

choices.label: Refuse — the people need those fields

effects.text: The fields stand. The enemy feeds themselves on your harvest.

events.name: Desert Caravans of the South
events.description: Routes through the desert bring exotic goods from sub-Saharan trading kingdoms.
events.flavourText: The camel drivers know routes that no map records. They have always known them.

choices.label: Let them find their own way

effects.text: The caravans pass without stopping. Cartada is not the destination today.

events.name: A Mountain Pass Opens
events.description: Spring thaw has opened a mountain pass that was believed impassable. Armies take note.
events.flavourText: The scouts return with snow still on their boots and a new route drawn in charcoal.

choices.label: Secure the pass with a garrison

effects.text: The pass is garrisoned. A new strategic option opens.
The pass remains unguarded. Others may find it useful.

events.name: The Wandering Scholar
events.description: A scholar of great learning, who has studied in three kingdoms, seeks a final home.
events.flavourText: He has read everything written in Al Rassan in the last three generations. He carries it in his head, and it is heavy.

choices.label: Offer the scholar a permanent home

effects.text: The scholar arrives with three carts of books and immediately begins teaching. The city is richer for it.
The scholar moves on. You hear later that he settled in a rival's city.

events.name: Blood Debt
events.description: In Al Rassan, blood spilled does not dry quickly. Every war creates feuds that outlast the peace.
events.flavourText: They remember who burned the village. They will remember for three generations.

effects.text: Blood spilled in Al Rassan does not dry quickly. The ledgers are kept.

diplomacyOptions.description: Offer peace terms to end the current state of war
Propose a formal alliance for mutual military and economic benefit
Declare open war and begin hostilities
Propose a temporary cessation of hostilities
Offer to become a vassal state in exchange for protection
Send a diplomatic message to another ruler
Propose a trade agreement for mutual economic benefit

tensionAxes.name: Religious Fervor
tensionAxes.description: Rises with religious techs and war between faiths. High values give combat bonuses vs the opposing religion but trigger persecution events and diplomatic penalties.

tensionAxes.name: The Muwardi Threat
tensionAxes.description: A global shadow rising over Al Rassan. Increases with each passing season, faster if the Asharite kingdoms fragment or fall. Above 70, the invasion chain begins.

flavor.settingDescription: Al Rassan glitters at the southern edge of the known world: a peninsula of cities, scholars, poets, and soldiers where three faiths circle one another in uneasy coexistence. To the north, the Jaddite kingdoms of Valledo and Ruenda hold the mountain passes and dream of reconquest. In the warm south, the Asharite Kingdoms of Cartada and Ragosa thrive in wealth and culture — but the old Caliphate at Qurtaba has crumbled, and the lions grow hungry. Between all of them move the silver-robed Kindath, merchants and physicians and astronomers, tolerated everywhere and safe nowhere. Yet the age of tolerance is ending. From across the sea, the Muwardi fundamentalists watch and wait. Their holy war has not yet come — but everyone who can read the stars knows it will. This is the last golden age, and it is already ending.
